author: nishant0
content: Hey is anyone doing any testing right now on devnet-12 ? I wanted to run some tests on prysm under conditions of non-finality in deneb. If no-one has any issues, devnet-12 would undergo a temporary period of non-finality. This should last at most around 15 epochs before reverting back to normal

author: barnabasbusa
content: If there is no opposition to this, I'll begin the non finality test in 10 mins!

author: barnabasbusa
content:
All prysm nodes have been shut down.
And: `lighthouse-nethermind-1,lighthouse-besu-1,lodestar-erigon-1,lodestar-geth-1,nimbus-geth-1,nimbus-reth-1,teku-reth-1,teku-reth-1-arm,nimbus-erigon-1-arm` have been shut down.

author: barnabasbusa
content: non finality event is over. Network recovered very quickly

author: barnabasbusa
content: I'm now resyncing all geth nodes with their new DB type. You might see slight reduction in participation for the next hour or two. (Finality shouldn't be affected)

author: parithosh
content: Here's an initial goerli blob analysis, we'd definitely need more time to collect data but it could be a useful first data point for ACD today: https://notes.ethereum.org/@ethpandaops/goerli-dencun-analysis

author: parithosh
content: afaik the last few we analyzed were all <@&898338229407870986> proposals

author: parithosh
content: Yeah that's a validator belonging to them

author: parithosh
content: afaik they arent dencun ready, but their validators are still proposing invalid blocks that are being ignored

author: tbenr
content: So, we could be us only in the case represented in the gist, and it is intentional. It seems possible that we do that for block with 0 commitments thus requesting all 6 blobs). Can you share the root of the 0 commitment block? How frequent is happening? Do you have the peerid?

author: terencechain
content:
dont have the peerid, but I will make an effort to log that. Thanks, it's a good feedback.
here is an example for block root `9368ad42e786c2765b81f67d7a4781f93a65feac17f8726a994d3d726591d8d6`  block contains 0 kzg commitment but we got all 6 blob by root request 2 slots later: https://gist.github.com/terencechain/305e2440e20b4bf9d00ff3c3bceb5f44

author: terencechain
content: I haven't seen it much today, not sure if it's because we are not spamming blobs or something else

author: tbenr
content:
from 2 colocated teku nodes. from slot 7419001 to 7423975.
NOTE: this timings are not strictly gossip latencies because teku can successfully retrieve missing blocks\blobs via RPC. It happened few times so the on aggregate we shouldn't see significant differences

https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1L-KrHKQZDacXyKbYtP34TDIlRsT-NSFmYYehvsr17bw/edit?usp=sharing

author: terencechain
content: I have minor feedback regarding MEV-Boost and builder testing. Currently, clients typically compare local and builder bids, opting for the local block if they match. In tests, as the mempool is identical and builders likely use standard Geth, I've noticed instances where the local bid equals the builder bid, leading Prysm to use the local block. Consequently, while the 'get header' part is tested, 'get payload' and 'submit blind block' remain untested. To address this, could we slightly increase the builder bid by adding a few more gwei each time? Not sure who to tag here, maybe <@539495253418180618>

author: marioevz
content: We do this in hive testing, we have a multiplier and an add-gwei value, but even with this, if the block has no transactions, the CLs sometimes catch this by using the txroot value (against the no-txs hash), and just use the local block instead

author: terencechain
content: Good flag. I wonder if the tx root check even makes sense. That piece of code that I added feels premature at this point

author: ralexstokes
content: i think the ideal setting would be realistic builder flow with the correct value in a block and private txs

author: ralexstokes
content: i’ll dm to chat a bit more

author: realbigsean
content: Doesn't kurtosis with `mev_type: full` have this?

author: realbigsean
content: it includes a builder, relay and `mev-flood` which I think has actual mev simulated

author: parithosh
content:
Yeah we run the builder from flashbots, so a fork of geth with a specific builder strategy and then mev-flood pointed to it that creates mev-able transactions. We have that stack in both kurtosis(local tests) and ansible (used for devnets).
It could ofc still happen that the local block is prefered, but it shouldnt be all the time - if it is, then one of our components must be out of funds or something

author: parithosh
content:

https://github.com/eth-clients/sepolia/pull/61

it sets the fork epoch for sepolia and holesky
